newsitem.title: CHINA: Sino-Russian trade seen topping $6 billion in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Sino-Russian trade seen topping $6 billion in 1996.

text.p: Sino-Russian trade is likely to total more than $6 billion in 1996, fuelled by increased Chinese demand for heavy industrial goods, the Business Weekly said on Sunday.
Trade between the two giant neighbours was $4.7 billion from January to August this year, a rise of 46.5 percent compared with the same period in 1995, the newspaper said.
China's imports of Russian goods jumped 67 percent during the eight months to total $3.67 billion, said the newspaper, which is published by the official China Daily.
Chief imports were chemicals, metal products and spaceflight products, it said. It did not say what China's main exports to Russia were.

"The development of certain fields of infrastructure construction this year have stimulated market demand for such heavy-duty Russian products as steel," the paper quoted Zhang Chunlai, an official with the China Foreign Trade Research Institute, as saying.
A cut in export tariffs and non-tariff barriers by Russia had also contributed to the rise in imports, Zhang said but did not elaborate.
Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov arrived in China on Sunday for an official visit.
Primakov started his visit in the country's industrial and commercial capital of Shanghai, where he will spend one day before meeting Chinese leaders in Beijing on Monday.
